column3: white-space:pre-wrap"">My favorite Disney Princess movie is definitely Beauty and the Beast, the tale as old as time. This Lego set is more recent, though. I wonder if this set will stand the test of time like its predecessor.

white-space:pre-wrap"">I like the disproportionate representation of Beauty and the Beast in this set. Beast has an appropriately dapper suit, befitting the ballroom scene. His oversized head is well-molded and opaquely printed. His alternate hair piece is also crisply detailed with several, fine lines.

white-space:pre-wrap"">Beauty (Belle) is quite stunning in her gold and yellow dress. The printing is simple, but effective. Her head and hair piece return from the past. However, they were already accurate and did not need to be updated. I am pleased with their return.

white-space:pre-wrap""><span style=""font-style:normal"">I was disappointed to not see Lumiere in this set. Thankfully, his good friend Cogsworth is here and maintains distinction throughout the facial printing. Madame de Garderobe is similarly portrayed, albeit larger. Nonetheless, the best servants are undoubtedly Mrs. Potts and Chip. They both have exquisite prints, even down to Chip&rsquo

white-space:pre-wrap""><span style=""font-style:normal"">The pop-up aspect of this set has not hindered the designer. The castle fits comfortably and is completely printed except for the stained glass window. The symmetrical model is no less eloquent than the previous renditions. Gold spires, cups, and a flag at the top add welcome flourishes to the build. I appreciate the round jumper tiles on top where Beauty and the Beast could stargaze if wanted. The front bridge lines up with the archway well and is very stable. The plant life is harmoniously depicted by Lego pieces and printing.&nbsp

white-space:pre-wrap"">Inside the castle, furniture is sparse. A bust for the Prince Adam hairpiece is plain, but rather necessary. The turntable in the center is adequate to reconstruct the ballroom scene. However, the magical rose certainly takes the cake. Its printing stands out on the transparent brick. I do not know why a brick was used instead of a more faithful dome. Yet, recreating the rose is already hard enough at this scale. I think the large quantity of stickers, especially in the back section of the model, is superfluous and I would leave them off of the model entirely.

white-space:pre-wrap"">The book is cleverly constructed and could easily be used for other purposes. I like the huge printed tile on the front cover depicting Belle. The engraving on the binding, exerting Lego as the publisher, is also a neat touch. I would have liked to see something more for the back cover.
white-space:pre-wrap"">Finally, the simple latch closes the set for transport with a lovely printed plate, just right for it.

white-space:pre-wrap"">The confined space of the book has not prevented the important aspects of this set from being included. My main complaint is the abundance of stickers and lack of Lumiere. Therefore, I would recommend this set, both for those who like to play

column2: s Storybook Adventure: In 2020 LEGO introduced a new form of Mini-Doll and a new type of buildable playset. In the vein of Polly Pocket and other similar smaller sized playset type sets comes the Storybook sets of LEGO Disney. Focusing on a single Princess character, each set includes a large clam-shell style pair of elements sculpted in the shape of a book and brand new Micro-Dolls. Smaller, child-sized Mini-Dolls with limited poseability.

column1: Sealed in a LEGO box designed to accommodate shelf space effectively, this box design shows a picture of the animated Princess in the bottom corner with the Disney Princess logo, and shows the set in its open and closed state to get an understanding of what you are purchasing. On the back we have some call outs to scenes from the movie recaptured in LEGO form alongside a very nice shot from the animated feature. It also demonstrates how to open the book and show off the other sets in the range.

The manual for this set is a bit less impressive. It is a massive let down compared to past LEGO Disney inspired sets, especially for a boxed set. Instead of an actual booklet you will find a small fold-open pamphlet style instruction manual similar to Polybags. This shows the detailed builds of each mini-model found inside the book, but has very limited space and so is exceptionally disappointing compared to other manuals. Even Polybag manuals tend to show each step-by-step build better and more efficiently than these larger designs.
The set also includes two sticker sheets, one which is actually used and the other which is meant for additional play options.

This set at this price range is sparsely populated with parts. You will find a lot of printed items, especially for the magical talking servants of the castle, but the bulk of the sets parts is made up of two large book sides and one book spine. There is also a printed Disney Princess element showing a nice silhouetted image of Belle&rsquo
column2: s animation model. Overall not a very effective parts pack.

column1: Beast: Micro-Dolls have no ability to grip accessories and their hands are too small to attach studs to. Their hands can fit the hair accessories into them though so you can have them hold bows or butterflies or other things which slide into the small holes in the Mini-Dolls hair.
Beast includes two different hair elements, a mask for his beast form and a regular head of hair for his transformed state. His torso is printed with his suit jacket form the Ballroom scene.

Belle: Her Micro-Doll is printed with the dress from the ballroom scene, which is still quite majestic looking despite being on such a tiny frame. A Micro-Doll is roughly have the height of a Mini-Doll, so these would make excellent toddlers in the regular Mini-Doll line.
Cogsworth: A single printed 1x1 brick with a stud on top makes up Cogsworth in this set, a bit less impressive than previous versions, but effective enough I suppose.
